Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 07:15PM janetwit wrote: I was dx in 2005 with bc mets to the liver.  Started on Abraxne and avastin.  After 3 rounds, wasn't working on the liver.  Onco put me on the standard 3 chemos taxol, adriximycin,(sp) and can't remember the other.  That didn't work so he was just going to put me on Arimidix.  I got a 2nd opinion at Emory Univ. in Atlanta.  The onco there said she wouldn't of used these chemo's.  So I got a 3rd.  I went on Carbo, that didn't work so they then stated I was a candidate for liver resection.  Had that in March 07 and wend on Xeloda for 6 months.  Remained cancer free until July 09. Tumors popped up again.  They did a 2nd surgery but 6 weeks later new tumors appeared.  I was then put on Ixempra. Didn't work, then I had intra-arterial chemo directly to the liver with Carbo. That didn't work.  Then I had theraspheres.  Tiny beads of radiation  injected directly  to the liver like the chemo.  This seems to have stabilized the liver for now, but he put me on halavan and x-geva. I'm still on arimidex to block all the hormones that may still be secreted.  They took out my ovaries when I had my 1st liver resection to keep the estrogen at bay.  Marsha, if your ER/PR + I'd be concerned about taking estrogen.  I can't even eat Soy.   Debra, you might check into theraspheres or some other form of radiation.  I have a friend that had BC recurrence to the liver and it was 80% cancer and she had TomoTherapy radiation and she's been cancer free for 6 years now.  Hope this information helps.  Best of luck to you and everyone else!!!
Posts.Title: Calling All Liver Mets-Need Input dragonfly stitchyphish

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 01:14PM janetwit wrote: Redskies,  Thanks for the info on estrogen treatment. I'm going to ask my onco about it on Wed.  That was a very interesting article and sounds very promising. Debra, Good luck with your 2nd opinion at Dana Farber.
Posts.Title: Calling All Liver Mets-Need Input dragonfly stitchyphish

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 03:07AM janetwit wrote: I've had the flu like symptoms and very tired as well.  I didn't have Neulasta after my 1st or 2nd treatment, I had nupogen injections for 4 days after the 2nd because they said the neulasta wouldn't have time to get my levels up within 2 weeks.  I go back on the 9th for my 3rd treatment. i guess that would be cycle 2.  My hair hasn't started coming out yet.  This will be the 4th time, if it does, and I'm not about hair anyway, so it really doesn't matter to me.  Each time I've lost it, it was this time of year, so I get to wear the cute hats and such.  I have a hot head in the summer, so I have to go bald.  If you saw my pic you can see, I have a big head, not a pretty site. (LOL)  I started on protonics today.  Seems to help.  I'd had it once before when I had theraspheres directly to the liver and it didn't seem to work. Dill pickles seem to help also.  Appetite has gone some too, but that is a good thing for me as well.  I need to drop some weight.  My energy seems to be better today than yesterday.  We've been snowed in for 3 days, so I probably have cabin fever.  Just need to be able to get out and gets some fresh air.  Good to hear what each of you are experiencing.  Hang in there.  We can all get this together.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 02:41AM janetwit wrote: My pre-meds consist of benedryl, Emend for nausea and Aloxi for long term nausea.  They used to give me decadron, but didn't this time around.  So glad.  Crashing after being on steroids can be worse than the side effects of the chemo.  I agree about the saltines.  I hate a whole pack over the weekend, and it does seem to help.  After just 3 doses of protonixs, my acid reflux is gone. We will beat this and hopefully this drug is the answer.  Wishing everyone a great weekend.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 12:44PM janetwit wrote: Hi Everyone,  I'm in the same boat as Annie.  I got word today that my WBC were 1.9 today, ( so my 4th treatment has been postponed again. Last treatment was 1-19.   I had Neupogen after 2nd treatment which was Jan 5th.  My doctor also wants mine to come up naturally.   I usually take Astragalus,  but I forgot to take it the last two weeks, so now I'm wondering it that is the reason.  My doctor put me on B6 + B complex for neuropathy. I've never had any problems in all the chemo's I've been on.  My WBC were 2.8 last week and platlets were to low.  So, I'm wondering why my WBC dropped when I didn't even have chemo.  Nurse said it could still be the effects of the chemo from the 19th.  All to confusing to me.  I'm just hoping and praying this is the right drug for all of us.  Wishing everyone a great week!

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 12:49AM janetwit wrote: Hello fellow halavenites.  Glad to hear the dill pickle suggestion worked.  My dad makes them every summer an actually told me to try that or pure vinegar.  I opted for the pickles.  My hair started thinning last weekend and was so thin on the sides that I just shaved my head yesterday.  I was tired of hair all over my clothes and in my face.  I've been so confused about how halaven is administered.  I finally figured it out this week.  I'm going to blame it on chemo brain.  I had my 1st dose of round 2 on Wed. Go back next Wed for 2nd.  They'll probably scan me after the completion of 3 rounds.  They'll give me my xgeva and either neulasta or neuprogen next week as well.  I've not had any bad side effects.  Just want to sleep all afternoon and haven't been out of the house.  It's so cold here, it's hard to get motivated but I'm determined to go to the mall tomorrow.   Now they're predicting snow again for next week.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 12:55PM janetwit wrote: I just order the Astragalus in liquid as well.  I had been taking a capsule. Constipated, oh my.   I have never had so much discomfort and pain.  I eat prunes, drink plum juice, take a stool softner and take milk of magnesia and try to eat as much high fiber foods as possible.  I've had to resort to enema's before.  Every chemo I've had, I've had this problem, but it seems to be worse on halaven, maybe because it is given more often.  He lowered the dose last time from 2.2 to 1.9, which I didn't think was very much, but I guess it was considerating how small the dose is to start with.  Pretty stong stuff in that small bag.    Good luck with the treatments and the weather.  I'm glad I didn't have to fly to Chicago in this mess today for my treatment.    Hope everyone has a great rest of the week.  Jan

This will be my 4th treatment.  They were at 88 last week, so I'm confused as to why I got treatment last week.  Can they be low for one treatment and not another?

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2011 12:22AM janetwit wrote: I was taking the Astragalus caps then switched this week to the liquid.  Hope it really helps.  I've also been on Melatonin 20mg for several years.  I never had any issues with my wbc until halaven.  My natropathioc doctor, (who is on staff at the hospital with my Onco) told me that seseme oil may help boost platlets by eating it, putting it on your skin, or bathing in it.  I have done this before and my platlets never dropped into a critical range, so it might me worth a try as well.  I buy a superfood from herbdoc.com that helps with energy.  Lots of good vitamins, esp. Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 02:14AM janetwit wrote: Jenn, Is your mets only to the liver?  If so, there is a treatment called theraspheres that I had.   I have multiple tumors in my liver.  I've been on 9 different chemos.  On Halaven(eribulin) now. Sometimes they'll do the theraspheres along with chemo.  Here is some info on it from the Cancer Treatment Center of America, where I receive my treatement. They were my 3rd opinion.  http://www.cancercenter.com/conventional-cancer-treatment/radiation-therapy/therasphere.cfm My liver tumors are currently stable after this treatment.  I have 2 small tumors on my spine now.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: today sucks; progression; new treatment jleigh JannyM

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 09:18PM janetwit wrote: I really don't know how many, but one is to many.  I started with BC mets to the liver.  Been on numerous chemos, most recently, intra-arterial carbo directly to the liver which didn't work.  2 surgeries, then they decided to do thera-spheres.   Last procedure in Sept.  Tiny mico size beads of radiation that is injected directly to the liver just like the chemo through the hepatic artery.  Easy procedure.  Mine are stable at the moment.  Now we're treating some spots that just showed up on my spine with Halaven and XGeva.  Good luck!!
Posts.Title: Liver Ladies jleigh Denny123

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2010 06:23PM janetwit wrote: Hi Sweetlife,  I go to CTCA in Zion, IL and you need to report that Dr.  I guarantee that he will either not do that again or will be fired.   Dr. Edgar Staren is the Vice President of Clinical Affairs for all of the CTCA facilities.  Call his assistance, Pauline Deruiter 847-731-5806 and give her the information.  She is wonderful and so is he.  This is not how CTCA practices medicine.  I've been coming here since Aug. 06.  I've never had a problem.  Dr. Staren was my surgeon and he told me once that he had to go to Phillie and fire a doctor because of his lack of ability to connect to his patients.  So, they are not afraid to terminate individuals. Also the part about not getting to see him is also not suppose to be happening.  I wish you luck and hope you can get resolution. Don't let him get away with treating you this way.
Posts.Title: Liver Mets Survivors gma5279 tami444

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2010 06:14PM janetwit wrote: Hi,  I'm another one that doesn't post but reads a lot of the great information.  I've had liver surgery twice.  Once in Feb 07 and then Aug 09.  I had a lumpectomy in Nov 05. Had chemo all of 06. Back on chemo now after they found another 3cm spot in Oct after my surgery in Aug09.   I was ER+PR weak + HER2-.  My tumors in my liver were the same as my breast.   Not sure why they would do surgery on her liver if they don't see anything.  The good thing about liver surgery is the liver does regenerate.  I wouldn't recommend liver surgery and a mastectomy at the same time.  Never heard of anyone doing that.  I'd be sure you have a surgical oncologist that specializes in liver surgery and the same for the breast.  Not just a general surgeon.  That was my 1st mistake.  I did great with the surgery.  Just got a ton of hernias afterwards.  If you haven't gotten a 2nd opinion, get one or two.  I go to the CTCA in Zion, IL.  They were my 3rd opinion.  I've been coming her since Aug 06.  Good Luck to the both of you.
Posts.Title: Liver Mets Survivors gma5279 tami444

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2011 07:59PM janetwit wrote: I'm confused as to why you dr. will tell you that.  I was dx in Nov 06 with bc and it was mets to the liver from the onset.  There are lots of options, some that don't involve chemo, like theraspheres.  I'd be finding another doctor as well and someone that is a specialist in BC and have him consult with a liver specialist.  Best of luck and keep us posted.  Don't give up, you have options!!
